thread.title: Auburn reports revenue record with help of SEC Network payout
thread.title_full: Auburn reports revenue record with help of SEC Network payout | AL.com

author: Brandon Marcello | bmarcello@al.com
title: Auburn reports revenue record with help of SEC Network payout
text:
The Auburn athletics department has reported a budget surplus of $1.9 million for the 2015 fiscal year, snapping a two-year stretch in which the department reported a deficit.
Auburn was buoyed by the distribution of $7.5 million from the SEC Network and a record $36 million in priority seating and gifts, according to the department.
Auburn generated a record total revenue of $123.9 million for the fiscal year, which ended in June, according to the department. The department spent $122 million. Expenses decreased by more than $5 million from the previous year.
The athletics department reported a deficit of $13.6 million in its NCAA financial report for the 2014 fiscal year . Reporting practices usually reveal different numbers between Auburn's in-house report and the NCAA's report.
Auburn's total expenses decreased year-over-year by more than $5 million, according to figures released by the school. Football accounted for 60 percent of the department's revenue ($24.8 million) and 23 percent of the expenses ($11.4 million).
Tickets sales generated $29.9 million for the school while Tigers Unlimited priority membership increased 14 percent, according ot the report. Priority seating generated $36 million for the department.
Auburn spent more than $15 million in upgrades over the last year at Jordan-Hare Stadium, including a videoboard priced at $13.9 million and $2 million in general improvements.
Auburn spent a total of $31.3 million on salaries for the fiscal year.
The NCAA's financial report usually differs from Auburn's fiscal reports in the fall. Auburn is expected to show a surpluss between $8 million and $9 million, according to the report. The adjustments in operating statements show the shift and are required by the NCAA.
Four percent of the budget was subsidized by student fees ($4.65 million). The department also set aside $5 million and transferred it to its deferred maintenance fund for future use.
Details on the department's reserve funds were not made available to AL.com. Those figures should be revealed in the school's NCAA financial report, which includes financial details from its private fundraising arm (Tigers Unlimited), in January.
